text: The senator’s comments were disgusting; I’m not disputing that. I’m saying that we shouldn’t treat the so-called egg boy as a hero, or act like that was an acceptable act for us to emulate. Repelling evil with wrong is against our sacred tradition. That’s it.

text: Umar al-Mukhtar al-Liybi رحمه الله

text: So what you’re saying about the headlock is a red herring. It’s diverting from what started the physical altercation. The white supremacist didn’t put the non-street savy young man in a headlock.
author: DawudWalid

text: The senator didn’t put that young man in a headlock. He hit him back after being assaulted. That young man isn’t a boy; he’s responsible for his actions - المكلف. If anyone hits someone with their hands or an object, they should expect retaliation. He played himself.
author: DawudWalid

text: We are not to repel evil with wrong meaning repelling a munkar with a munkar. Our scholars for centuries have written about that adab of enjoining good and forbidding evil. Our feelings are important, but what we feel is acceptable in countering evil should not be our criterion.

text: It’s not from the Prophetic sunnah to hit someone with our hands or objects for saying intolerant or racist things. We shouldn’t be trying to defend that. The men piling on him point is a red herring, sister.
